works.abstract: The chapter explains why propositional meaning and formal semantics are dispensed with in favor of two other conceptions of meaning: meaning as intention and meaning as knowledge. works.title: Literacy and Language
works.abstract: The chapter argues why language has changed more rapidly in the literate part of human evolution. It describes the invention of writing by the Sumerians, and presents an outline of the main writing systems in modern languages. works.title: The Problem of Continuity in Time and Across Domains
works.abstract: The chapter addresses continuity in language evolution and continuity across behavioral domains. It compares human language and communicative behavior by subhuman primates and discusses Bickerton’s assumptions of a protolanguage. works.title: Dialogues as Procedural Skills
works.abstract: Early dialogues are learned as procedural skills, and have a special role in the evolution of language. Vocal turn-taking by marmoset monkeys, which resembles turn-taking by human infants, serves as pre-adaptation to linguistic communication by humans. works.title: The Modality-Independent Capacity of Language: A Milestone of Evolution
works.abstract: The chapter makes a distinction between language impairment and production errors such as apraxia, dysarthria and speech sound disorders. It argues against the gestural theory of language evolution and for the evolution of a “general language bias.” Hence, the chapter introduces the concept of a modality-independent capacity of language. works.title: Developmental Language Impairment: Conceptual Issues and Prospects of an Evolutionary Approach
works.abstract: The concept of specific language impairment (SLI) is discussed and abandoned in view of recent research. The co-morbidity of developmental language impairments and other neurodevelopmental disorders (for example, deafness), show that language difficulties are rarely specific to language. works.title: Developmental Language Impairment: Perspectives of Etiology and Treatment
works.abstract: The chapter argues for a renewed discussion of developmental language impairment within the conceptual frameworks of Ullman’s procedural-declarative model and Saffran’s constrained statistical learning paradigm. works.title: Language Evolution and Developmental Impairments
works.abstract: This book gives an account of developmental language impairment from the perspective of language evolution.
